network_generator_V2.add_objs_from_templates(file: str, templates, grid_name: str, o_IntPrj: Optional[pflib.pf_typing.IntPrj] = None, validate_input_data: bool = True, csv_format: Optional[Dict[str, str]] = None)[source]

Add objects using templates. It is assumed that a template contains only one object of type ElmSym or a ElmGenStat. This object will be connected to the grid and the power plant for this object will be imported automatically.

Parameters

  • file – input data with the objects to import

  • templates – templates folder object

  • grid_name – loc_name of the ElmNet

  • o_IntPrj – project object

  • validate_input_data – validate input frames

  • csv_format – csv format, default delimiter=”,” decimal=”.”

Parameters

  • o_IntPrj – PF project

  • overwrite – if the library already exists it will be overwritten

the imported PF library

lines.correct_incoherent_cables(df_lines: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Correct incoherent data in the cables column

Parameters

df_lines (pd.DataFrame) – lines DataFrame

Returns

lines DataFrame without incoherent cables

Return type

pd.DataFrame

The number of cables should always be a multiple of 3 because we are considering that all circuits are 3-phased

lines.format_lines(df: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Format lines DataFrame

Parameters

df (pd.DataFrame) – lines DataFrame

Returns

formatted lines DataFrame

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Get relevant information from tags and put it in the DataFrame’s columns. Calculate the length of each line using calculate_line_length() and compute each line’s connecting line using find_connecting_segments().

lines.query_lines() → str[source]

Overpass API query to be run

Param

Returns

query string

Return type

str

The query looks for lines and cables with a voltage value >= 100kV inside the area of Austria and filters out the lines and cables with a frequency of 16.7Hz, which belong to the railway system.

lines.split_lines_by_voltage(df_lines: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Split lines with more than one voltage level into multiple lines (one for each voltage level)

Parameters

df_lines (pd.DataFrame) – lines DataFrame

Returns

lines DataFrame containing lines with a single voltage level per line

Return type

pd.DataFrame

When the number of voltage levels is the same as the number of circuits a line is assigned to each voltage level (a line here is equivalent to a row of the DataFrame). When the number of voltage levels is different from the number of circuits we distinguish two cases:

  • number_of_circuits % number_of_voltage_levels == 0: we assign a line to each voltage level, but now the line has a number of circuits equal to:

    number_of_circuits / number_of_voltage_levels

  • number_of_circuits % number_of_voltage_levels != 0: we look if the references are known (there’s one reference for each circuit):

    • references are known: we assign a line to each voltage level and the number of determined by the references

    • references are not known: TODO

lines.split_middle_connections(df: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Split lines that are connected to other lines at some point which is not its start or end

Parameters

df (ps.DataFrame) – lines DataFrame

Returns

lines DataFrame without any middle connection

pd.DataFrame

TerminalsGenerator

terminals.assign_areas_and_zones(df_subs: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Assign areas and zones to terminals using NUTS (Nomenclature of Territorial Units for Statistics)

Parameters

df_subs (pd.DataFrame) – terminals DataFrame

Returns

terminals DataFrame with assigned zone and area

Retype

pd.DataFrame

NUTS2 regions define the areas and NUTS3 define the zones. Tieline terminals are assigned the code ‘TL’ for the area and the zone fields.

terminals.convert_substation_areas(df_subs: pandas.DataFrame) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Transform substations to circular geometries

Parameters

df_subs (pd.DataFrame) – substations DataFrame

Returns

substations DataFrame with new geometry

Return type

pd.DataFrame

Uses the Mercator projection to find the Hausdorff distance between the substation’s centroid and the substation’s perimeter. Then creates a circle with a minimum radius of 200 meters and proportional to the Hausdorff distance. And finally converts the circle to GPS coordinates and assigns it as the substation’s geometry.

power_plants.load_atlas_data(csv_file) → pandas.DataFrame[source]

Get solar generation installations data from https://www.statistik.at/atlas/

Parameters

csv_file (str) – path to csv file with new data

Returns

DataFrame with formatted new solar installations data

Return type

pd.DataFrame

The new solar power plants data is based on the installed PV systems supported by the funding initiatives Climate and Energy Fund and OeMAG. The data shows the output kW per 1000 inhabitants of the PV systems installed in each municipality of Austria.

main.handle_floating_ends(df_lines: pandas.DataFrame, df_subs: pandas.DataFrame) → tuple[pandas.DataFrame, pandas.DataFrame][source]

Assign a terminal to line ends which are still not connected anywhere

Parameters

  • df_lines (pd.DataFrame) – lines DataFrame

  • df_subs (pd.DataFrame) – terminals DataFrame

Returns

  • df_lines (pd.DataFrame) - lines DataFrame with assigned floating end terminals

  • df_subs (pd.DataFrame) - terminals DataFrame with new floating end terminals appended

Get lines with at least a floating end. If they have a substation nearby (less than 1 km), assign substation to line and add the length value corresponding to the missing segment. Otherwise, add a new terminal to the floating end. If the line end is outside the region of Austria, the line is a tieline and a substation is added at the floating end.

main.handle_special_cases(df_lines, df_subs, df_trafos) → tuple[pandas.DataFrame, pandas.DataFrame][source]

TODO: Detailed explanation

main.qgis(df_lines: pandas.DataFrame, df_subs: pandas.DataFrame, df_trafos: pandas.DataFrame, df2: pandas.DataFrame, df_pp: pandas.DataFrame, df_pp_agg: pandas.DataFrame, df_loads: pandas.DataFrame) → int[source]

Create csv files to visualize data using QGIS desktop application

Parameters

  • df_lines (pd.DataFrame) – lines DataFrame

  • df_subs (pd.DataFrame) – terminals DataFrame

  • df_trafos (pd.DataFrame) – transformers plants DataFrame

  • df2 (pd.DataFrame) – substations DataFrame with original geometries (before converting to circles)

  • df_pp (pd.DataFrame) – power plants DataFrame

  • df_pp_agg (pd.DataFrame) – power plants DataFrame with aggregated distributed generation

  • df_loads (pd.DataFrame) – loads DataFrame

Returns

0

Return type

int

Create csv files with attributes and WKT geometries to visualize the data of the model in QGIS. This way layers can be added to the QGIS project using the “Add Delimited Text Layer…” operation. The terminals had to be separated into two different files because QGIS can only read data with the same WKT type for each file. For the power plants also two files are created: one contains the power plants at the original location and before being aggregated and the other contains the aggregated power plants located at the position where their assigned terminal is positioned.
